content: <div>I had been in the corps for almost three years, rotating through land and water survival instruction,
learning how to fly a T-38 (a really fast jet!) and space shuttle systems training.
But all candidates look forward to spacewalk training in the Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory (NBL).
The NBL has a huge pool holding six million gallons of water and houses a complete model of the International
Space Station. Working underwater provides the closest simulation of a space environment. Doing well in
underwater training can help move you up the list for a mission to space.
Mastering the work is difficult. For one thing, the Extra Vehicular Activity (EVA) dive suits make you
look like a cross between the Pillsbury Doughboy and the Michelin Man. It can be clumsy and slow to
But this was it. It was my chance to prove my skills and be considered for a flight assignment.
I was all suited up and excited as they lowered me into the water.

content: When I reached a depth of ten feet, I noticed that a little block of Styrofoam was missing from my helmet. It’s called a
Valsalva Pad, and it’s attached at nose level to help you clear your ears as you descend.
When I began to feel fullness in my ears, I told the test director that the pad was missing. He asked if I wanted to return
to the surface to have one installed.

slides.template: flex-columns malibu cover cover-x-0 cover-y-0 max-width-1000
content: Going back up would mean a delay and I was intent on getting through the training exercise and showing my mastery of the
Another few feet and my ears felt really full, the pressure building like you might feel in an airplane that makes a really
Twenty feet below the surface, the pressure was painful. I knew something was really wrong.
I tried speaking to the surface crew but got no reply.
“I can’t hear you,” I said, louder this time. “Can you turn the volume up?”
I strained to hear a reply, but only got static in return. The pain in my ears kept increasing as I waited for a reply.
“Turn up the volume!” I shouted into the microphone.
Why were they ignoring me on deck?
The pain in my ears was almost unbearable. I was relieved to feel the cable reverse and begin to pull me back toward
Once I was poolside with my helmet off, things became surreal. Everyone around me was just mouthing words. There was no
The flight surgeon kept looking at the right side of my head, checking my ear lobe.
He reached up and felt my right ear. When he pulled his finger back, I saw the blood on his finger. My ear was bleeding.
I had severe hearing loss in both ears. I went through a series of tests and exploratory surgery, but no one could explain
My sudden deafness was a medical mystery.
<figcaption>Some days the only thing that got me through was the love and support of my friends.</figcaption>
I had been on top of the world, confident that I would do what only a handful of people had ever done–perform spacewalks 240
Losing my hearing meant my status changed to “DNIF” - Duty Not Involving Flying.
I had faced my share of failure, but this time it felt different. It felt permanent.
I was truly a penguin–a flightless astronaut.
